overview_of_class:
This seminar is intended to help students become better consumers and producers of
quantitative, qualitative and mixed methods causal inference. Whereas the former will
make you a better colleague to fellow social scientists, the latter improves your job
prospects (and get you colleagues to begin with). Based on the potential outcomes
framework, this class will introduce students to qualitative and quantitative techniques
that enable researchers to isolate causal effects. It will force students to move beyond
"naive" regression and case study designs and explore how "less naïve" combinations of
both methods can strengthen our confidence in causal claims. It does this by
emphasizing the importance of research design and making explicit the assumptions
underlying causal arguments.

overview_of_class: Inequalities, their varied forms, reproduction, transformations and, potentially, eradication - have been core concerns of sociology since its inception as a discipline. However, attention to the particular dimension of class has grown dramatically in recent years, both in sociology and in other social science disciplines. In this seminar, we take an interdisciplinary approach and integrate this newer focus on class with ongoing research on other dimensions of inequality. We also focus on the role of politics - broadly construed to include systems of beliefs and ideology, culture, electoral systems, social movements, states - in creating, sustaining or eroding inequalities of various kinds.

overview_of_class: This seminar is designed to expose students to the realm of sociological research (and research in other disciplines, notably history) that addresses how we think about and memorialize the past. How is history constructed? How are historical events shaped and made socially meaningful? Who are the shapers and who are the shaped?

overview_of_class: The United States leads the world in the reliance on the mass imprisonment and solitary confinement of its citizens as an institutionalized mechanism of crime and social control. This course will consider the causes of mass incarceration and its consequences in America. Topics considered will include relationships between welfare support and imprisonment, the rise and fall of punishment regimes, the connection between total incapacitation and solitary confinement, the impact of mass incarceration on inmates and families, links between intensive policing and imprisonment, and the politics of inmate reentry and reform in American society.
